nodes.text: Absolute intergenerational income mobility in the United States has declined since 1940 and this decline is driven more by how GDP growth is distributed across the income distribution than by aggregate GDP growth rates alone

We estimate rates of absolute income mobility (fraction of children earning at least as much as their parents) for birth cohorts 1940 to 1984 by combining marginal income distributions with the copula of parent and child income ranks

Data inputs: marginal child income distributions from CPS (March supplements), parents' marginal distributions from pooled decennial census IPUMS samples, and copula estimated from de-identified IRS tax records for 1980-1982 cohorts

For cohorts before 1980 (no panel copula), we assume copula stability as a benchmark and compute nonparametric upper and lower bounds on absolute mobility by searching over all plausible copulas satisfying first-order stochastic dominance using linear programming
Baseline measure: pretax family income at age 30 in 2014 dollars (CPI-U-RS); sensitivity analyses vary deflators, taxes/transfers, ages, family size adjustments, and individual vs family income
Result: Under the copula-stability benchmark, absolute mobility fell from about 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to about 50% for the 1984 birth cohort (measured at age 30)

Result: Declines in absolute mobility occurred across the income distribution but were largest in the middle and upper-middle of the parental income distribution (example: 50th percentile fell from 93% to 45%; 90th from 88% to 33%)

Heterogeneity result: Absolute mobility declined in every U.S. state between 1940 and 1980 (larger declines in industrial Midwest) and shows gender differences when using individual earnings (sons' chances fell sharply; daughters' pattern differs due to rising female labor force participation)

Sensitivity results: The decline is robust to alternative price deflators, accounting for taxes and transfers (small increase in levels), measuring income at age 40, adjusting for family size, and plausible upward adjustments to reported child income

Bounding evidence: For early cohorts (e.g., 1940) bounds over all plausible copulas are tight (e.g., 84% to 98%), showing copula uncertainty does not alter the conclusion of a large decline; bounds widen for recent cohorts where copula matters more

Counterfactual method: Construct two counterfactual income distributions for the 1980 cohort â€” (a) higher GDP growth (apply 1940s growth rate to 1980 cohort but allocate 2010 GDP by 2010 income shares), (b) more broadly shared growth (apply 1940 income shares to observed 2010 GDP)

Counterfactual result (higher GDP growth): If GDP per family had grown at midcentury rates but distribution remained as in 2010, absolute mobility for the 1980 cohort would rise modestly to about 62% (closing ~29% of the gap to 1940 levels)

Counterfactual result (more broadly shared growth): If 2010 GDP were allocated across households as in the 1940 cohort, absolute mobility for the 1980 cohort would rise to about 80% (reversing over 70% of the decline)

Interpretation/Conclusion: Much of the decline in absolute mobility arises from a more unequal distribution of economic growth; raising aggregate growth alone, without a broader distribution, is unlikely to restore midcentury absolute mobility rates

Limitation/Assumption: Copula for cohorts prior to 1970 is not observed; analysis relies on copula stability benchmark plus bounding with FOSD constraints, and some assumptions about parents' income measurement windows and representativeness of late childbearing incomes
